title: Dow jumps 300 points as earnings season heats up
text:
* The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA was up 305 points, or 0.9%, at 34,715.

* The S&P 500 SPX rose 42 points, or 1%, to 4,434.

* The Nasdaq Composite COMP gained 165 points, or 1.2%, to trade at 13,497.

On a quiet Monday with several international markets shut, the Dow fell 40 points, or 0.1%, while the S&P 500 edged down 1 point and the Nasdaq Composite lost 0.1%. The S&P 500 has dropped for seven of the last nine sessions.

What's driving markets

This week is one of the busiest in the U.S. quarterly earnings reporting season, after a raft of banks posted somewhat disappointing results last week.

Johnson & Johnson JNJ headlined the companies reporting ahead of Tuesday's open, and International Business Machines Corp. IBM and Netflix Inc. NFLX report after the close.

Netflix shares have been hammered this year, skidding 44%, on investor concern about their subscription numbers.

The average implied earnings move for S&P 500 companies based on options prices is plus or minus 4%, according to strategists at UBS. That's a bit lower than the fourth quarter of 2021, but above the 10-year average, the strategists said.

Need to Know: Here are 30 stocks that Goldman Sachs likes when economy stutters and markets gyrate

The International Monetary Fund on Tuesday said the war in Ukraine will lead to a significant slowdown in global economic growth this year, though the institution isn't forecasting recession or stagflation for the U.S. or Europe.

The IMF said global growth would slow to a 3.6% rate this year, down from 6.1% in 2021 and 0.8 percentage points lower than in the last forecast in January. Still 3.5% growth is in line with long-run trends. The U.S. economy is expected to grow at a 3.7% rate this year, down from the prior estimate of 4%.

Data showed U.S. March housing starts and permits each roseby less than 1%.

The U.S. economic calendar also features a speech by Chicago President Charles Evans.

The airlines sector will be in the spotlight as well after a U.S. federal judge halted the mask mandate on planes, a move that the industry championed.

Companies in focus

* Johnson & Johnson shares rose 3% after the pharmaceutical and consumer products company topped first-quarter profit expectations but missed on revenue, and cut its full-year outlook.

* American Campus Communities Inc. ACC on Tuesday confirmed a report by The Wall Street Journal that it agreed to be acquired by Blackstone Inc. BX in a deal that values the student housing company at about $12.8 billion including debt. American Campus shares rose nearly 13%, while Blackstone shares were were up 3.5%.

* Hasbro Inc. HAS shares rose 4% after the toymaker missed first-quarter profit estimates.

* Twitter Inc. TWTR was expected to turn down Tesla Inc. TSLA Chief Executive Elon Musk's offer for the social-networking company, while The Wall Street Journal reported late Monday that private-equity powerhouse Apollo Global Management Inc. APO was considering whether to join in a bid. CNBC later reported that Apollo's interest was focused on lending money to potential purchasers, not on a private-equity-style buyout. Twitter shares were down 2%.

How other assets are trading

* The yield on the 10-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y rose 5 basis points to 2.912%. Yields and debt prices move opposite each other.

* The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, a measure of the currency against a basket of six major rivals, was up 0.1%.

* Bitcoin BTCUSD rose 1.8% to trade above $41,500.

* Oil futures CL.1 pulled back from April highs, with the U.S. benchmark down 4.7% below $103 a barrel. Gold futures GC00 shed 1.2% to trade below $1,963 an ounce.

* The Stoxx Europe 600 XX:SXXP fell 0.8% as European traders returned from a four-day Easter weekend, while London's FTSE 100 UK:UKX lost 0.1%.

* The Shanghai Composite CN:SHCOMP posted a loss of less than 0.1%, while the Hang Seng Index HK:HSI fell 2.3% in Hong Kong and Japan's Nikkei 225 JP:NIK rose 0.7%.
